an6.63:4.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you a penetrative explanation of the teaching.
an6.63:4.2: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
an6.63:5.1: “Mendicants, what is the penetrative explanation of the teaching?
an6.63:5.2: Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.
an6.63:6.1: Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.
an6.63:7.1: Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.
an6.63:8.1: Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.
an6.63:9.1: Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.
an6.63:10.1: Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.
an6.63:11.1: ‘Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’ That’s what I said,
an6.63:11.2: but why did I say it?
an6.63:11.3: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
an6.63:11.4: Sights cognizable by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Sounds cognizable by the ear …
an6.63:11.7: Touches cognizable by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
an6.63:11.8: However, these are not sensual pleasures. In the training of the noble one they’re called ‘kinds of sensual stimulation’.
an6.63:12.1: ‘Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.
an6.63:12.2: The world’s pretty things aren’t sensual pleasures.
an6.63:12.3: Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.
an6.63:12.4: The world’s pretty things stay just as they are,
an6.63:12.5: but a sage removes desire for them.’
an6.63:13.1: And what is the source of sensual pleasures?
an6.63:14.1: And what is the diversity of sensual pleasures?
an6.63:14.2: The sensual desire for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches are all different.
an6.63:14.3: This is called the diversity of sensual pleasures.
an6.63:15.1: And what is the result of sensual pleasures?
an6.63:15.2: You create a life-form that corresponds to your desires, with the attributes of either good or bad deeds.
an6.63:16.1: And what is the cessation of sensual pleasures?
an6.63:16.2: When contact ceases, sensual pleasures cease.
an6.63:16.3: The practice that leads to the cessation of sensual pleasures is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an6.63:16.4: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
an6.63:17.1: When a noble disciple understands sensual pleasures in this way—and understands their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation—they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of sensual pleasures.
an6.63:17.2: ‘Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:17.3: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an6.63:18.1: ‘Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:18.3: but why did I say it?
an6.63:19.1: And what is the source of feelings?
an6.63:20.1: And what is the diversity of feelings?
an6.63:20.2: There are ~carnal pleasant feelings, ~spiritual pleasant feelings, ~carnal painful feelings, ~spiritual painful feelings, ~carnal neutral feelings, and ~spiritual neutral feelings.
an6.63:20.3: This is called the diversity of feelings.
an6.63:21.1: And what is the result of feelings?
an6.63:21.2: You create a life-form that corresponds to your feelings, with the attributes of either good or bad deeds. This is called the result of feelings.
an6.63:22.1: And what is the cessation of feelings?
an6.63:22.3: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an6.63:22.4: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
an6.63:23.1: When a noble disciple understands feelings in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of feelings.
an6.63:23.3: ‘Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:23.4: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an6.63:24.1: ‘Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:24.3: but why did I say it?
an6.63:24.5: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and phenomena.
an6.63:25.1: And what is the source of perceptions?
an6.63:26.1: And what is the diversity of perceptions?
an6.63:26.2: The perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and phenomena are all different.
an6.63:26.3: This is called the diversity of perceptions.
an6.63:27.1: And what is the result of perceptions?
an6.63:27.2: Communication is the result of perception, I say.
an6.63:27.3: You communicate something just as you perceive it, saying ‘That’s what I perceived.’
an6.63:27.4: This is called the result of perceptions.
an6.63:28.1: And what the cessation of perception?
an6.63:28.3: The practice that leads to the cessation of perceptions is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an6.63:28.4: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
an6.63:29.1: When a noble disciple understands perception in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of perception.
an6.63:29.2: ‘Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:29.4: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an6.63:30.1: ‘Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:30.3: but why did I say it?
an6.63:30.5: the defilements of sensuality, desire for rebirth, and ignorance.
an6.63:31.1: And what is the source of defilements?
an6.63:31.2: Ignorance is the source of defilements.
an6.63:32.1: And what is the diversity of defilements?
an6.63:32.2: There are defilements that lead to rebirth in hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, the human world, and the world of the gods.
an6.63:32.3: This is called the diversity of defilements.
an6.63:33.1: And what is the result of defilements?
an6.63:33.2: A person who is deluded and ignorant kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”
an6.63:34.1: And what is the cessation of defilements?
an6.63:34.3: The practice that leads to the cessation of sensual pleasures is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an6.63:34.4: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
an6.63:35.1: When a noble disciple understands defilements in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of perception.
an6.63:35.2: ‘Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:35.4: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an6.63:36.1: ‘Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:36.3: but why did I say it?
an6.63:36.4: It is choice that I call deeds.
an6.63:36.5: For after making a choice one acts
an6.63:36.6: by way of body, speech, and mind.
an6.63:37.1: And what is the source of deeds?
an6.63:38.1: And what is the diversity of deeds?
an6.63:38.2: There are deeds that lead to rebirth in hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, the human world, and the world of the gods.
an6.63:38.3: This is called the diversity of deeds.
an6.63:39.1: And what is the result of deeds?
an6.63:39.2: The result of deeds is threefold, I say:
an6.63:39.3: in this very life, on rebirth in the next life, or at some later time.
an6.63:39.4: This is called the result of deeds.
an6.63:40.1: And what is the cessation of deeds?
an6.63:40.3: The practice that leads to the cessation of deeds is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an6.63:40.4: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
an6.63:41.1: When a noble disciple understands deeds in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of deeds.
an6.63:41.2: ‘Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’
an6.63:41.3: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an6.63:42.1: ‘Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.’
an6.63:42.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
an6.63:42.3: Birth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you want is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.
an6.63:43.1: And what is the source of suffering?
an6.63:43.2: Craving is the source of suffering.
an6.63:44.1: And what is the diversity of suffering?
an6.63:44.2: There is suffering that is severe, mild, slow to fade, and quick to fade.
an6.63:44.3: This is called the diversity of suffering.
an6.63:45.1: And what is the result of suffering?
an6.63:45.2: It’s when someone who is overcome and overwhelmed by suffering sorrows and pines and cries, beating their breast and falling into confusion. Or else, overcome by that suffering, they begin an external search, wondering:
an6.63:45.3: ‘Who knows one or two phrases to stop this suffering?’
an6.63:45.4: The result of suffering is either confusion or a search, I say.
an6.63:45.5: This is called the result of suffering.
an6.63:46.1: And what is the cessation of suffering?
an6.63:46.3: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an6.63:46.4: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
an6.63:47.1: When a noble disciple understands suffering in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of suffering.
an6.63:47.2: ‘Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.’
an6.63:47.3: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
an6.63:48.1: This is the penetrative explanation of the teaching.”
